properties.name: Eco-Builder
properties.description:
Welcome to EcoCity Builder, a tile-based strategy game where urbanization meets environmental responsibility. In this engaging and educational game, players are tasked with building and expanding cities while managing the delicate balance between progress and sustainability.

As you create urban tiles—such as houses, high-rises, and power stations—your city will thrive, generating valuable resources like gold. However, with progress comes a cost: carbon emissions. It’s up to you to reduce these emissions by planting trees, which absorb carbon and help maintain a stable environment. But beware! Space is limited, and strategic placement of your tiles is essential to prevent environmental disasters.

The game’s first three levels offer an easy introduction, making it fun and accessible for all ages, while the last two levels introduce more challenging scenarios that test your ability to manage urban growth and environmental health.

In EcoCity Builder, your goal is not just to create a booming metropolis but to ensure that it remains sustainable for the future. With future updates planned to add more complex environmental systems—such as oceans, natural disasters, and environmental events—players will face an ever-evolving challenge of balancing progress with the health of the planet.

Can you build a thriving city while keeping carbon emissions in check? Play EcoCity Builder and find out!

Tree:

Give : 1  Food/ cycle
Reduces : 1 carban / cycle

objects.name: NewText
objects.string:
You've built your first house! 🏡  Every house you build contributes to urban development, but it also increases carbon emissions. To combat this, remember to plant trees, which help absorb CO₂ from the atmosphere! 🌳  
   
Learn more about the GLOBE protocols and how communities can work together to track environmental changes: [https://www.globe.gov/]

content.text:
You've built your first house! 🏡  Every house you build contributes to urban development, but it also increases carbon emissions. To combat this, remember to plant trees, which help absorb CO₂ from the atmosphere! 🌳  
   
Learn more about the GLOBE protocols and how communities can work together to track environmental changes: [https://www.globe.gov/]

objects.name: NewText
objects.string: You've established a farm! 🌾  Farms play a crucial role in food production but can also impact the environment. Ensure you balance your farming activities with reforestation to maintain a healthy ecosystem. Remember, trees help absorb the carbon produced by your farm! 🌍  Explore the scientific process behind sustainable agriculture and its effects on the environment: [https://www.globe.gov/do-globe/resources/student-resources/be-a-scientist/steps-in-the-scientific-process]

objects.name: NewText2
objects.string:
You've constructed a power plant! ⚡  Power plants are vital for energy supply but can significantly contribute to carbon emissions. Keep an eye on your carbon footprint by ensuring you have enough trees planted to offset the emissions! 🌲  

Check out the GLOBE Visualization System to see how data is collected globally and how it can help in understanding local environmental impacts: [https://vis.globe.gov/GLOBE/]

content.text:

Check out the GLOBE Visualization System to see how data is collected globally and how it can help in understanding local environmental impacts: [https://vis.globe.gov/GLOBE/]

objects.name: NewText2
objects.string:
You've created a high-rise building! 🏙  High-rises maximize urban space but can lead to increased emissions. Striking a balance between urbanization and nature is essential for sustainability. Remember, every tree counts in this balance! 🌿  
Access the GLOBE Advanced Data Access Tool for additional data and insights to further your understanding of urban development and its environmental impacts: [https://datasearch.globe.gov/]

objects.name: NewText
objects.string:
You've completed the final level with a sustainable urban environment! 🌆  In addition to your high-rises, you’ve built a water plant to ensure a steady supply of clean water for your community. Balancing urbanization with natural resources is key to sustainability! 🌍💧  
Discover more about Earth's observation data and how it can help inform decision-making in sustainable practices at the EODMS: [https://www.eodms-sgdot.nrcan-rncan.gc.ca/index-en.html]

content.text:
You've completed the final level with a sustainable urban environment! 🌆  In addition to your high-rises, you’ve built a water plant to ensure a steady supply of clean water for your community. Balancing urbanization with natural resources is key to sustainability! 🌍💧  
Discover more about Earth's observation data and how it can help inform decision-making in sustainable practices at the EODMS: [https://www.eodms-sgdot.nrcan-rncan.gc.ca/index-en.html]

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteSlider
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value.
description: A draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value. The slider can be customized with sprites.
There are ready-to-use sliders in the asset-store [settings UI pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=settings-ui-settings-ui).

eventsBasedObjects.description: Let users select a numerical value by dragging a slider.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelSpriteSlider

events.comment: This allows to detect a change of "intial value" on hot reload.
Create the label that is displayed over the thumb.
Pass the configuration to the behavior.

Children instances must be resized when the parent size change:
- background is resized to take the full dimensions of the parent
- the label is put back at the center of the bar

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

parameters: max(Background.BoundingBoxRight(), max(Label.BoundingBoxRight(), Thumb.BoundingBoxRight())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxLeft(), min(Label.BoundingBoxLeft(), Thumb.BoundingBoxLeft()))
max(Background.BoundingBoxBottom(), max(Label.BoundingBoxBottom(), Thumb.BoundingBoxBottom())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxTop(), min(Label.BoundingBoxTop(), Thumb.BoundingBoxTop()))

events.comment: The parent size is not defined in onCreate so it needs to be done here.

events.comment: This allows to detect a change of "intial value" on hot reload.
Create the label over the bar.
Pass the configuration to the behavior.

Children instances must be resized when the parent size change:
- background is resized to take the full dimensions of the parent
- the bar size is refreshed according to the value
- the label is put back at the center of the bar

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ButtonStates
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Use any object as a button and change appearance according to user interactions.
description: Use the "Button states" behavior to track user interactions with an object, including:
- Hovered
- Pressed
- Clicked
- Idle
Add additional behaviors to make juicy buttons with animated responses to user input:
- Size
- Color
- Animation
- Object effects

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ShakeObject
description: Shake an object (position, angle or scale).
It can be used for:
- Hit or impact
- Object slowly rocking back and forth (like a ship)
- Simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
The top-down RPG example uses this extension for damage animations ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://top-down-rpg)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle).
This behavior can be used on any type of object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle

eventsFunctions.description: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle). Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters.
eventsFunctions.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake object _PARAM0_ for _PARAM2_ seconds. Modify position amplitude _PARAM3_ on X axis and _PARAM4_ on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM5_.  Wait _PARAM6_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM7_

events.comment: Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake

parameters.description: Amplitude of postion shake in X direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of position shake in Y direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.longDescription: Use a negative number to make the single-shake move in the opposite direction.
parameters.name: PowerY

parameters.description: Amplitude of angle rotation shake (in degrees)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerAngle

parameters.description: Amount of time between shakes (in seconds) (Default: 0.08)
parameters.longDescription: For a single-shake effect, set it to the same value as "Duration".

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: HexagonalGrid
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Snap objects to an hexagonal grid.
description: It allows to snap objects on an hexagonal grid.
It's useful for:
- level editors
- building systems ([open the city builder example online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://city-builder))
A [simple example](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://snap-object-to-grid) shows how to snap objects that are dragged with the mouse.

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToPointyToppedHexagonalGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

inlineCode: // Find the hexagon cube coordinates for a given position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// Hexagon cube coordinates to hexagon position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// const positionX = Math.sqrt(3) * roundX  + Math.sqrt(3)/2 * roundZ;

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual row height will be 3/4 of this.
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd rows are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 3/4" offset to make it the other way.
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToFlatToppedHexagonalGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

events.comment: Note: this is the exact same code as for pointy topped hexagonal grid with x and y swapped.

inlineCode: // Find the hexagon cube coordinates for a given position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// Hexagon cube coordinates to hexagon position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// const positionX = Math.sqrt(3) * roundX  + Math.sqrt(3)/2 * roundZ;

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual column width will be 3/4 of this.
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd columns are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 3/4" offset to make it the other way.
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual bubble grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual bubble grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToBubbleGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual bubble grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

events.comment:
This grid is like bottles stacking, odd lines are shifted from half a cell. 

On an hexagonal grid a line height is 3/4 of sprite height but with bubbles it is sin(60°) that is around 0.866 which is near 7/8 = 0.875
(7/6)/(3/4) = 7/6
Using this ratio, the cellHeigt gives the 7/8 line height and this allows integer position as assets are often a multiple of 8.

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual row height will be 7/8 of this.
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd rows are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 7/8" offset to make it the other way
parameters.name: OffsetY
